position.marginalia_text: Brederodi Tabula Pandectarum; necessaria, et utilissima Synopsis Digestorum: nec quicq[uam] pra[e]gnantius tam serio, solidoq[ue] Compendio: tam ad ipsam praxin forensem, quàm ad artem ciuilem. Aureum Alphabetum Mnemonicon. Logica cuiusq[ue] Materia[e] ratio, supplenda ex Qua[e]stionibus Justinianeis: ex his Paratitlis Pandectarum: ex Analysi Consiliorum Zasij: maximeq[ue] ex ipsa Logica Jureconsultorum. Qua[e] in primis necessaria ad unguem. Solus adhuc Freigius Analysi Juris Dialectica[e] operam dedit: vt Genesi solus Vulteius primum; nunc etiam tandem Althusius. Ipsa Ciuilis ratio enucleatiùs exposita ab Hoppero, libro 4. Elementorum; et libris 4. ad Pandectas. Pragmatica ratio subtiliùs distincta à Nicasio in Institutiones; Decio, et Dyno in regulas vtrisq[ue] Juris; Bartholo in Digesta; Baldo in Codicem; Durando in Speculo Juris; Maranta in aurea praxe.

Iuris civilis sive ad Pandectas libri sex

X-ref.book_title: Lectura super titulo de regulis iuris

marginalia.translation: Brederode's table of the 'Digest' is extremely useful, an indispensable synopsis, and not something more pregant than a serious, solid compendium, as much for public practice as for civil art. The mnemonic 'Alphabetum aureum'. The logical approach to its material is to be supplied from the 'Quaestiones iustinianeae', from this 'Paratitla', from Zasius's analysis of opinions, and most of all from the 'De logica iureconsultorum'. This is, to be clear, what is necessary first and foremost. Thus far, only Freigius has gone to the trouble of analysing law by dialectic, as firstly Vulteius did with Genesis and finally Althusius likewise. The civil approach is more simply explicated by Joachim Hoppers in book four of the 'Elementorum', and in the four books of the 'Ad Pandectas'. The pragmatic approach is more subtly distinguished by Nicasius in the 'Super institutionibus', by Decio and Dinus on the rules of law, by Bartolus on the 'Digest', by Baldo on the 'Codex Justinianus', by Durand in the 'Speculum iucidiale', and by Maranto in the 'Aurea praxis'.
